Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: On the occurrence, origin, and intake of the nuclides, <sup>210</sup>Po and <sup>210</sup>Pb, in sclerotia of Wolfiporia cocos collected in China.

AbstractText: The dried sclerotium of the fungus Wolfiporia cocos is edible and has medicinal value. This study aimed to understand the accumulation of radioactivity arising from the alpha <sup>210</sup>Po, and beta-emitting <sup>210</sup>Pb, in the sclerotium's shell and core and assess a potential effective dose for consumers. Sclerotia were collected in the wild and from cultivars in China's Anhui and Yunnan provinces. The mean values of <sup>210</sup>Po activity concentration levels were 0.36 Bq kg<sup>-1</sup> dry weight in the core and 12.0 Bq kg<sup>-1</sup> dw in the shell; <sup>210</sup>Pb activities were 0.43 and 9.84 Bq kg<sup>-1</sup> dw, respectively. The potential effective radiation doses from core layers (as a major raw material of the sclerotium) ranged from 0.13 to 3.43 µSv kg<sup>-1</sup> dw from <sup>210</sup>Po decay and from 0.11 to 1.52 µSv kg<sup>-1</sup> dw from <sup>210</sup>Pb decay. Corresponding values for shell ranged from 0.80 to 42.4 for <sup>210</sup>Po and from 0.53 to 13.6 µSv kg<sup>-1</sup> dw for <sup>210</sup>Pb. In general, the intake of W. cocos sclerotia varies between consumers, but this would not significantly change the effective radiation doses from <sup>210</sup>Po and <sup>210</sup>Pb isotopes. The consumption thus appears to be safe from a radiological protection point of view.
